comments:
Marketing 396 provides a detailed introduction to the role of merchandising at various retailers, including apparel and other softlines businesses, grocery stores, mass-merchandisers and "category killers". Selected topics may include product development, line planning, sourcing, product lifecycle, forecasting, planning and allocation, pricing and markdowns, and vendor relations.

Students were generally surprised by the content of the course, describing it as “heavy on the ‘fashion’ aspects of retail.” While one student described the course as “perhaps the best introduction to fashion retailing one could have hoped for,” a number of students were disappointed, saying that the course had “too much focus on retail aspect, not enough on business aspect” and did not meet their “expectations of providing a general overview on the importance of merchandising in ANY retail environment or how merchandising affects marketing.” One student commented that the course felt “like an FIT class,” and another student was surprised at “the level of detail [students] were required to go into on garments and the amount of fashion creation/creative idea generation required for the course.” A number of students praised the “amazing [guest] speakers” that were brought to their class.

Students described Professor Sheridan as “passionate about her subject matter,” “outstanding and genuinely a great teacher.” Students said that she “is clearly an expert in the field,” explains material in a “crisp, enthusiastic way,” “makes the subject very accessible, and is very approachable to those who are not familiar with the fashion industry.”

Students generally agreed that there was “a lot of work for a .5 credit unit” and that there were “too many assignments.” A number also expressed concerns that assignment grading rubrics and expectations were “hard to decipher.” Marketing 396 is a .5 credit, one-half term course and can be taken towards a marketing concentration. The prerequisites are Marketing 101 and Marketing 255.
